posts.name: saketh kantipudi
posts.cooked:
Hi Everyone,

Our team is designing a mechanism that we want a little more rigidity with, so we want to use a 3/4in shaft, but the one problem is bearings. We can’t seem to find 3/4in hex shaft or bearings anywhere reasonably. We don’t have much experience with Keyed round shafts apart from motor pinions but are open to. Can any team that has used shaft diameters larger than .5 hex or round share their experiences.

posts.name: ridge478
posts.cooked: McMaster Carr is usually a good start

posts.name: Owen Busler
posts.cooked:
McMaster-Carr is the complete source for your plant with over 595,000 products. 98% of products ordered ship from stock and deliver same or next day.

Just a few which is odd… did i do a bad search?

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: Assuming this is for an arm, might I suggest 7/8" OD tube instead? The bushings you can find on McMaster for 7/8" OD tube play very nicely with the 1.25" hole in COTS sprockets.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked:
Reject bearings, embrace oil embedded bushings:

McMaster-Carr is the complete source for your plant with over 595,000 products. 98% of products ordered ship from stock and deliver same or next day.

posts.name: Sean Lavery
posts.cooked:
Hex shaft is a fairly specialized product to FRC. It’s not really a common industry standard. Hex bearings, in particular, are a product driven very heavily by FRC demand.

You can find 3/4" Hexagon Bars from various vendors and various materials, like McMaster . They can likely function as shafts for FRC purposes, but may not be as perfectly straight or uniform as products intended to be used as rotary shafts. Hex Bearings, on the other hand, aren’t going to be as easy to find in 3/4", although you could potentially use an bushing and broach it out to a hex bore (and then even potentially place that bushing inside a larger ball bearing).

A better option may be investigating the use of tube shaft, such as either the 3/4" tube or MaxSpline shaft sold by Rev. https://www.revrobotics.com/ion/structure/

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: Here is a purchase order that we intend to place soon for a 7/8" dead axle high torque arm setup. Feel free to copy.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: No, you did a perfectly good search. The closest McMaster-Carr has to 3/4" hex bearings is 11/16" hex bearings (which is, admittedly, only 1/16" smaller) and they do have corresponding 11/16" aluminum hex shaft as well. You could also get that in steel of various alloys, but at that point do you really need to?
Oil embedded bushings are actually really great. Consider them if you cant find anything better

posts.name: kgzak
posts.cooked: 7/8 bushings are 1.125 O.D. not 1.25. 1in bushings are 1.25 though.

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked: Fortunately 1.125” is the correct dimension to play nice with other typical COTS bearings in FRC.

posts.name: Noah Eckfeldt
posts.cooked: Friendship ended with bearings now bushings are my best friend

posts.name: kgzak
posts.cooked:

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: 6338K479 (and kin) and 2938T56 (and kin) will work just fine, and both are in stock.

posts.name: kgzak
posts.cooked: That is indeed what we did, just thought it was funny that he posted about using them and now they are out of stock.

posts.name: 1024Jerry
posts.cooked: 11/16 hex is the industry standard for heavy duty conveyor applications, which is why there are a lot of options for that size.  That makes it a great choice.
